be withheld in the event that

team will be composed of Harold
Yudkin, chairman; John Mount
and either Louis Kroll or Leon
Back.

Seven Hopkins Professors Sign Petition Favoring Entrance into
International Justice Court

Seven professors at the Johns
Hopkins University are represented
on the petition signed by 304 Maryland citizens who are urging Amerjean adherence to the W
World Court.
They are: Dr. Joseph S. Ames,
President of the Hopkins; Dr.
Broadus Mitchell, associate professor of political economy; Dr. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, professor of
philosophy ; Dr. William H. Welch,
professor of the hIstory of medi_
eine ; Dr. John H. Latane, member
of the Walter Hines Page School;
John V. A. MacMurray, direc_
tor, Walter Hines Page School of
International Relations; Dr. Raymond Pearl, professor of biology,
School of Medicine.
The petition reads:
The undersigned citizens of Maryland earnestly urge upon the U. S.
Senate, the approval of that body
to the adherence of the United States
to the Permanent Court of International Justice, also known as the
World Court, and the ratification of
the World Court protocols and statute, with the amendments thereto,
including what is known as the Root
formula, as recommended by the
President of the United States.

Table Discussion on
China

On Saturday, January 24, Miss
Lizette W. Reese, prominent poet,ess, will address the members of
the Cosmopolitan Club of Baltimore, it was recently announced.
At a recent meeting of the club,
Dr. Johannes Mattern, assistant
librarian at the Johns Hopkins
University, led a round table discussion concerning the present state
of affairs in China. Approximately forty students, representing
many nations, attended the meeting and took part in the discussion.

HONOR FRATERNITY
Dowell, Warlow Named Yesterday To National Undergraduate Organization
DR. AMES DELIVERS
PRINCIPAL ADDRESS
Praises Society Highly;
Outlines Purpose and Activities of 0. D. K.
George H. Dowell and Franci
C. Warlow yesterday were elected
to the Omicron Delta Kappa national honorary fraternity at the assembly at which Dr. Joseph S.
Ames, the Hopkins president was
the principal speaker.
Both Johns Hopkins students, to
be graduated in June, were named
to the fraternity in recognition of
their outstanding services to the
thliversity.
In stating the purpose of 0. D.
K., Dr. Ames declared: "The purpose of the Omicron Delta Kappa
honorary fraternity is to recognize
in an outstanding way the qualities
by which young men- think students
can be of service to the University.
It aims to select those men who
have been of outstanding service to
Hopkins."
Ames Commends Fraternity

Declaring he regarded his own
election to 0. D. K. as an exceptional honor, the President called
the fraternity the "greatest help in
the whole student body" during the
five years he was dean. Cases were
cited in which the fraternity was
approached for aid in matters pertaming to the campus. As stated
by Dr. Ames, the members gave
evidence at all times of "knowing
everything that was going on about
the college."
Attributing the recognition, by
awards, of outstanding athletes as
the reason for the organized state
of college sports, the Hopkins president asserted that despite the fact
there is no evident way to reward
scholarship, better results would
nevertheless be attained were
scholarship adjudged.
Discusses Curriculum Changes

Dr. Ames, in digressing from the
theme of his address, declared the
extensive changes were being made
in the College of Arts and Sciences
with the view of riding out some
way by which students may be required to definitely decide what they
intend to do.
Failure will ultimately face the
newly adopted plan by which the
point-credit system was abolished,
it is the President's belief, if the
student body fails to recognize the
responsibilities placed upon themselves by the system to be inaugurated in 1932.
Student Co-operation Essential

"The authorities of the College
can readily provide methods if the
undergraduate upperclassmen definitely decide upon the subject in
which their main interest lies," he
said at the 0. D. K. assembly.
"There are rare cases in which a
man in a college seeks knowledge
for himself," continued the' speaker.
"We do not know the vital means
by which to make your ambitions a
force in your lives as college men.

EDITORIALS
R. O. T. C.

P. T.

C. at the Hopkins is a dignified and respected branch of
R• 0.theT.academic
program. Why is this? It is because the course,
as presented, is well-planned, well-executed. As a consequence, it is
recognized by the administration as being of quality and is awarded
collegiate points toward graduation.
Physical training at the University is a farce! It is regarded with
amusement and ridicule by the undergraduates, as a whole. Why is
this? Because of the apparent unorganization and the inefficiency of
the course. Then, too, although it is required for graduation in some
form or another, this requirement is not rigidly enforced and the
authorities will not recognize it as vitally important enough to be
worthy of graduation points. In our opinion, the physical training
branch of the curriculum could have been dignified by the administration by putting it on a par with the R. 0. T. C. and making its lectures
and quizzes events of importance.
Just a comparison of opinions on these two undergraduate courses,
voiced in any group discussion will bring out the distinction which is
in the students' minds.
Now that the new non-credit system is to be inaugurated, the
incentive to join the "army" for the five points will be obliterated.
Will, considering that, more students take the "snap" P. T. course, or
will more spend their first two years dragging guns around? Or will
the R. 0. T. C. degenerate to the class of the present P. T.;
Of course, we all know that the government checks received in the
third and fourth years are a tremendous drawing card for some of the
soldiers, but how many feel it until they reach the end of their two
years' work required for graduation.
Along with this, is the idea of including athletics with P. T. as an
alternative for R. 0. T. C. Now that the point system is going out of
power, will the athletic field be swamped with frail young pacifists
who desire to keep as pure and unadulterated as possible? Or will
some of the more viril of the army men who no longer will be able to
get credits from their weekly drills decide to give the coaching staff
the benefits of their manly physiques;
The change to the comprehensive examination system is fine for the
purely academic studies, but what effect will it have on the three
branches of activities mentioned above?
F. C.

O. D. K.
to the two men who were initiated into
0UR0.D.congratulations
K. yesterday, George Dowell and Francis Warlow. This
initiation, as far as our limited knowledge goes, is the smallest ever
held to the most coveted honor on the campus.
But with the initiation of but two seniors to this honorary fraternity,
to the highest of honors at the Johns Hopkins, the question arises in
the minds of those interested, "Is this honorary association, acknowledged the greatest honor a senior can achieve on the campus, dying?
In almost every election in the past, one or more juniors have been
admitted to the inner sanctum of this august group. This year there
are some worthy juniors who could have been admitted without depreciating the value of 0.D. K. Since these men may not get into the
fraternity until next spring, at the end of this year's activity, they will
not be imbued with the feelings, desires and aims of the group enough
to carry on the good of the body which guides campus activities.
We do, however, extend our heartiest congratulations to the men
who were admitted yesterday, but hope that the next election will find
F. C.

SIMILES
Collecting unusually good similes has proved of great interest to
F. J. Wilstach, compiler of "A
Dictionary of Similes." Rummaging through his collection reveals a
number of laughs.
We read of the lady who was so
thin that she could fall through a
flute and never strike a note. Benj.
De Casseres remarked that the face
of the world looks as though it had
shaved itself with a broken beerbottle, standing on a barrel in a
cyclone. The vividness of the remark that "he gurgled like an
empty sink" is most amazing, while
we are greatly soothed to know
that "she is tender, caressing like a
trip-hammer." 0. 0. McIntyre observes that the gentleman was "as
distinguished as the light on a taximeter." The expression that "it
is as false as a night-club hostess's
sigh" is heart-rending. The Chicago Daily News triumphantly declared that "he is as self-effacing
as a Treasury surplus under Andrew Mellon's glare."
Mark Twain interjects that "the
smile faded from his face like
breath off a razor." The New
York World sets forth that "it was
as fascinating as watching a man
with the palsy trying to pick up a
puddle of mercury." While an
anonymous wit declares "it was so
still you could hear the microbes
gnashing their teeth." It was
proudly asserted that "she was so
thin, her full face looked like a
profile." "He was as stingy as the
man who tried to send a nightletter during an eclipse." H. C.
Witwer chimes in with "he was
about as calm and collected as a
man with St. Vitus' dance walking over Niagara Falls on a tight
rope during a hurricane."
The remark that "she threw herself it him like a medicine ball," is
only topped by the fact that "her
mouth opened like a folding bed."

The little foundry has grown into the
347 acres of Crane manufacturing
plants. Progress has brought rows
of giant electric furnaces to take the
place of his first crude one. The lightning rod couplings that he made on
that day in 1855 have been expanded
into a line of 33,000 items, meeting
every modern valve and fitting need
of the world's industries. But to this
day, the example the founder set of
intense personal interest and pride
and care for the quality ofeach product remains a distinguishing mark
of the Crane organization.

tention to, that is coins. With much

much drudgery, Dr. Robinson

well-preserved silver coins of the

After making its initial bow last
Friday night at the Pro Cathedral,
the Johns Hopkins Musical Club
advanced another step in its annual
concert tour by appearing before an
audience at the Mount Vernon M.
E. Church last Tuesday night.
Both concerts featured a vibrant
enthusiasm on the part of the members of the club. The concert at the
Pro Cathedral was somewhat of a
dress rehearsal for the bigger
events to follow. On the whole, the
concerts were well attended and
evidently appreciated.
The next concert will take place
tonight at the Forest Park Presbyterian Church. The members
of the Musical Club are looking
forward to their visit to the Mary-land College for Women at Lutherville on February 7, and also the
concerts to be held at Port Deposit,
Cumberland, and other proposed
cities.

George Darley's Black and Blue
basketball squad met a tartar in
Georgetown University last Tuesday night at Evergreen and
dropped a 30-16 decision to the
Hilltoppers. The Washington quintet was a fast, experienced group
of players who were continually

ease while the Jays seemed unable
to get started.

Critic Calls Recital Music of Late Romantic Period "Cheap Sentimentalism" •

Dr. Laurence A. Petran presented a recital in Levering Hall
last Tuesday, which consisted of a
group of light numbers, all of them
played in a very charming and delightful manner. The compositions
were chosen from the period in music known as the "late .romantic
period." The earmark of such compositions is "dressed up sentimentalism." This consists of compositions written in a very sugary
style with runs and frills which are
absolutely unnecessary in the composition. There has been a violent
reaction to such music and that period is hardly ever heard on the
concert platform except in the composition of Chopin and Liszt.

The second half started with
Shea and Dillon scoring for the
Washington team before the
Homewood quint could get organized. Then a foul by Don Kelly
enabled Bozek to add another point
via the free throw route. This was
reciprocated when Bozek fouled
the guard a moment later and Kelly
made good.
After Shea and Mac Zees scored
'field goals for the Hoyas, the Kelly
brothers combined to get another
one from scrimmage, Caleb taking
a fast pass from his brother and
scoring from beneath the basket.
Mac Zees gathered another point
on a free throw and then Shea and
Bozek scored from scrimmage. Don
Kelly put a long one through the
netting and then Bozek scored his
fourth field goal of the evening.
Another goal by Don Kelly was
made just before the final gun
sounded.
Kelly Shines For Hopkins

Kelly's shooting and Silverman's
passwork were the bright lights for
Hopkins. Aside from their quick
passwork the winner's features
were the shooting of Shea and Bozek and Dillon's recoveries from
the backboards after attempted
shots. Deficiency in this work cost
the home team several points.

the work of excavating this old

granted in a recent interview. Since
his return to America from that
first expedition, Dr. Robinson has

in his department: Miss Dorothy
Hill, Mr. Walter Graham, Mr. and
Mrs. Parsons, Miss Freeman (who
will make the drawings), Miss
Ross and Miss Davidson.

Seven Hopkins Professors Sign Petition Favoring Entrance into
International Justice Court

Seven professors at the Johns
Hopkins University are represented
on the petition signed by 304 Maryland citizens who are urging Amerjean adherence to the W
World Court.
They are: Dr. Joseph S. Ames,
President of the Hopkins; Dr.
Broadus Mitchell, associate professor of political economy; Dr. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, professor of
philosophy ; Dr. William H. Welch,
professor of the hIstory of medi_
eine ; Dr. John H. Latane, member
of the Walter Hines Page School;
John V. A. MacMurray, direc_
tor, Walter Hines Page School of
International Relations; Dr. Raymond Pearl, professor of biology,
School of Medicine.
The petition reads:
The undersigned citizens of Maryland earnestly urge upon the U. S.
Senate, the approval of that body
to the adherence of the United States
to the Permanent Court of International Justice, also known as the
World Court, and the ratification of
the World Court protocols and statute, with the amendments thereto,
including what is known as the Root
formula, as recommended by the
President of the United States.

Dowell, Warlow Named Yesterday To National Undergraduate Organization
DR. AMES DELIVERS
PRINCIPAL ADDRESS
Praises Society Highly;
Outlines Purpose and Activities of 0. D. K.
George H. Dowell and Franci
C. Warlow yesterday were elected
to the Omicron Delta Kappa national honorary fraternity at the assembly at which Dr. Joseph S.
Ames, the Hopkins president was
the principal speaker.
Both Johns Hopkins students, to
be graduated in June, were named
to the fraternity in recognition of
their outstanding services to the
thliversity.
In stating the purpose of 0. D.
K., Dr. Ames declared: "The purpose of the Omicron Delta Kappa
honorary fraternity is to recognize
in an outstanding way the qualities
by which young men- think students
can be of service to the University.
It aims to select those men who
have been of outstanding service to
Hopkins."
Ames Commends Fraternity

Declaring he regarded his own
election to 0. D. K. as an exceptional honor, the President called
the fraternity the "greatest help in
the whole student body" during the
five years he was dean. Cases were
cited in which the fraternity was
approached for aid in matters pertaming to the campus. As stated
by Dr. Ames, the members gave
evidence at all times of "knowing
everything that was going on about
the college."
Attributing the recognition, by
awards, of outstanding athletes as
the reason for the organized state
of college sports, the Hopkins president asserted that despite the fact
there is no evident way to reward
scholarship, better results would
nevertheless be attained were
scholarship adjudged.
Discusses Curriculum Changes

Dr. Ames, in digressing from the
theme of his address, declared the
extensive changes were being made
in the College of Arts and Sciences
with the view of riding out some
way by which students may be required to definitely decide what they
intend to do.
Failure will ultimately face the
newly adopted plan by which the
point-credit system was abolished,
it is the President's belief, if the
student body fails to recognize the
responsibilities placed upon themselves by the system to be inaugurated in 1932.

can readily provide methods if the

man in a college seeks knowledge
for himself," continued the' speaker.

by which to make your ambitions a

EDITORIALS
R. O. T. C.

P. T.

C. at the Hopkins is a dignified and respected branch of
R• 0.theT.academic
program. Why is this? It is because the course,
as presented, is well-planned, well-executed. As a consequence, it is
recognized by the administration as being of quality and is awarded
collegiate points toward graduation.
Physical training at the University is a farce! It is regarded with
amusement and ridicule by the undergraduates, as a whole. Why is
this? Because of the apparent unorganization and the inefficiency of
the course. Then, too, although it is required for graduation in some
form or another, this requirement is not rigidly enforced and the
authorities will not recognize it as vitally important enough to be
worthy of graduation points. In our opinion, the physical training
branch of the curriculum could have been dignified by the administration by putting it on a par with the R. 0. T. C. and making its lectures
and quizzes events of importance.
Just a comparison of opinions on these two undergraduate courses,
voiced in any group discussion will bring out the distinction which is
in the students' minds.
Now that the new non-credit system is to be inaugurated, the
incentive to join the "army" for the five points will be obliterated.
Will, considering that, more students take the "snap" P. T. course, or
will more spend their first two years dragging guns around? Or will
the R. 0. T. C. degenerate to the class of the present P. T.;
Of course, we all know that the government checks received in the
third and fourth years are a tremendous drawing card for some of the
soldiers, but how many feel it until they reach the end of their two
years' work required for graduation.
Along with this, is the idea of including athletics with P. T. as an
alternative for R. 0. T. C. Now that the point system is going out of
power, will the athletic field be swamped with frail young pacifists
who desire to keep as pure and unadulterated as possible? Or will
some of the more viril of the army men who no longer will be able to
get credits from their weekly drills decide to give the coaching staff
the benefits of their manly physiques;
The change to the comprehensive examination system is fine for the
purely academic studies, but what effect will it have on the three
branches of activities mentioned above?

to the two men who were initiated into
0UR0.D.congratulations
K. yesterday, George Dowell and Francis Warlow. This
initiation, as far as our limited knowledge goes, is the smallest ever
held to the most coveted honor on the campus.
But with the initiation of but two seniors to this honorary fraternity,
to the highest of honors at the Johns Hopkins, the question arises in
the minds of those interested, "Is this honorary association, acknowledged the greatest honor a senior can achieve on the campus, dying?
In almost every election in the past, one or more juniors have been
admitted to the inner sanctum of this august group. This year there
are some worthy juniors who could have been admitted without depreciating the value of 0.D. K. Since these men may not get into the
fraternity until next spring, at the end of this year's activity, they will
not be imbued with the feelings, desires and aims of the group enough
to carry on the good of the body which guides campus activities.
We do, however, extend our heartiest congratulations to the men
who were admitted yesterday, but hope that the next election will find

SIMILES
Collecting unusually good similes has proved of great interest to
F. J. Wilstach, compiler of "A
Dictionary of Similes." Rummaging through his collection reveals a
number of laughs.
We read of the lady who was so
thin that she could fall through a
flute and never strike a note. Benj.
De Casseres remarked that the face
of the world looks as though it had
shaved itself with a broken beerbottle, standing on a barrel in a
cyclone. The vividness of the remark that "he gurgled like an
empty sink" is most amazing, while
we are greatly soothed to know
that "she is tender, caressing like a
trip-hammer." 0. 0. McIntyre observes that the gentleman was "as
distinguished as the light on a taximeter." The expression that "it
is as false as a night-club hostess's
sigh" is heart-rending. The Chicago Daily News triumphantly declared that "he is as self-effacing
as a Treasury surplus under Andrew Mellon's glare."
Mark Twain interjects that "the
smile faded from his face like
breath off a razor." The New
York World sets forth that "it was
as fascinating as watching a man
with the palsy trying to pick up a
puddle of mercury." While an
anonymous wit declares "it was so
still you could hear the microbes
gnashing their teeth." It was
proudly asserted that "she was so
thin, her full face looked like a
profile." "He was as stingy as the
man who tried to send a nightletter during an eclipse." H. C.
Witwer chimes in with "he was
about as calm and collected as a
man with St. Vitus' dance walking over Niagara Falls on a tight
rope during a hurricane."
The remark that "she threw herself it him like a medicine ball," is
only topped by the fact that "her
mouth opened like a folding bed."

After making its initial bow last
Friday night at the Pro Cathedral,
the Johns Hopkins Musical Club
advanced another step in its annual
concert tour by appearing before an
audience at the Mount Vernon M.
E. Church last Tuesday night.
Both concerts featured a vibrant
enthusiasm on the part of the members of the club. The concert at the
Pro Cathedral was somewhat of a
dress rehearsal for the bigger
events to follow. On the whole, the
concerts were well attended and
evidently appreciated.
The next concert will take place
tonight at the Forest Park Presbyterian Church. The members
of the Musical Club are looking
forward to their visit to the Mary-land College for Women at Lutherville on February 7, and also the
concerts to be held at Port Deposit,
Cumberland, and other proposed
cities.

George Darley's Black and Blue
basketball squad met a tartar in
Georgetown University last Tuesday night at Evergreen and
dropped a 30-16 decision to the
Hilltoppers. The Washington quintet was a fast, experienced group
of players who were continually
moving and garnered points with
ease while the Jays seemed unable
to get started.

Critic Calls Recital Music of Late Romantic Period "Cheap Sentimentalism" •

Dr. Laurence A. Petran presented a recital in Levering Hall
last Tuesday, which consisted of a
group of light numbers, all of them
played in a very charming and delightful manner. The compositions
were chosen from the period in music known as the "late .romantic
period." The earmark of such compositions is "dressed up sentimentalism." This consists of compositions written in a very sugary
style with runs and frills which are
absolutely unnecessary in the composition. There has been a violent
reaction to such music and that period is hardly ever heard on the
concert platform except in the composition of Chopin and Liszt.

The second half started with
Shea and Dillon scoring for the
Washington team before the
Homewood quint could get organized. Then a foul by Don Kelly
enabled Bozek to add another point
via the free throw route. This was
reciprocated when Bozek fouled
the guard a moment later and Kelly
made good.
After Shea and Mac Zees scored
'field goals for the Hoyas, the Kelly
brothers combined to get another
one from scrimmage, Caleb taking
a fast pass from his brother and
scoring from beneath the basket.
Mac Zees gathered another point
on a free throw and then Shea and
Bozek scored from scrimmage. Don
Kelly put a long one through the
netting and then Bozek scored his
fourth field goal of the evening.
Another goal by Don Kelly was
made just before the final gun
sounded.
Kelly Shines For Hopkins

Kelly's shooting and Silverman's
passwork were the bright lights for
Hopkins. Aside from their quick
passwork the winner's features
were the shooting of Shea and Bozek and Dillon's recoveries from
the backboards after attempted
shots. Deficiency in this work cost
the home team several points.
